instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2838: What is 820-2838? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not booting/no chime
threads.message: Hi Guys I have a 2838 that was just dead. No signs of liquid spil. Replaced <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and now i got fanspin and orange light, however its not booting. CPU gets hot, I have 32clk on Y2810. CPU Vcore is 1V (should it be 1.25?). Will check now <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> but cant find i.e. <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>/1950. Im not experience with these old boards, how should I troubleshoot this further?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not booting/no chime
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not booting/no chime
threads.message: Resistance to ground on PP3v42 = 2.586k ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not booting/no chime
threads.message: That's way too low. Dead MCP more than likely

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2838</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not booting/no chime
threads.message: Does not sound good. I doubt this antique is worth putting time into. Bad MCP is very likely indeed.
